column2: string"">1.1 added rdfs:isDefinedBy for all named entities</owl:versionInfo>
string"">Created by Aldo Gangemi and Valentina Presutti</owl:versionInfo>
PlainLiteral"">She greeted us all in her various roles of mother, friend, and daughter.</cpannotationschema:scenarios>

PlainLiteral"">The time indexed person role CP available at http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/cp/owl/timeiindexedpersonrole.owl allows to represent temporariness of roles played by persons. It can be generalized for including objects or, alternatively the n-ary classification CP avaliable at http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/cp/owl/naryclassification.owl can be specialized in order to obtain the same expressivity.</cpannotationschema:relatedCPs>

PlainLiteral"">This CP allows designers to make assertions on roles played by agents without involving the agents that play that roles, and vice versa. It does not allow to express temporariness of roles.</cpannotationschema:hasConsequences>
PlainLiteral"">To represent agents and the roles they play.</cpannotationschema:hasIntent>
PlainLiteral"">which agent does play this role?

column1: what is the role that played by that agent?</cpannotationschema:coversRequirements>
<rdfs:comment>Any agentive Object , either physical, or social.</rdfs:comment>
<!-- Generated by the OWL API (version 3.1.0.1602) http://owlapi.sourceforge.net -->
>What species are present in this aquatic resource/stock? In what water area this aquatic resource/stock lives in?</cpannotationschema:coversRequirements>
>To represent aquatic resources or stocks as composed of aquatic organisms from one or more species, and living in a water area.</cpannotationschema:hasIntent>

>Relations between aquatic resources and either aquatic species or water areas can be represented. In order to infer what species typically live in what water areas however, an application needs to add a SWRL rule, or a SPARQL query that unifies the hasSpecies and hasWaterArea relations.</cpannotationschema:hasConsequences>
>give me the Species for water area 24</cpannotationschema:scenarios>
>give me the Water areas for species Gadus morhua</cpannotationschema:scenarios>
>A fishery resource (a collection of actual aquatic organisms) that can include aquatic organisms from different AquaticSpecies, and is localized in some WaterArea.
It can be mapped to fi:AqResRef</rdfs:comment>
>Aquatic species are conceptual entities that are characterized together with resources and water areas.
Mappable to fi:Species, fi:SpeciesRef, fi:SpeciesFeature, etc.

It has related axioms from FIGIS Schema that are included in the classes linked to the fi:Species class, such as fi:SpeciesRef (holding association with fi:AqResRef, which holds association with fi:WaterAreaRef).</rdfs:comment>
>A physical water area. Mappable to fi:WaterAreaRef</rdfs:comment>
<!-- Generated by the OWL API (version 2.2.1.1138) http://owlapi.sourceforge.net -->

column2: string"">1.1 added rdfs:isDefinedBy for all named entities</owl:versionInfo>

string"">It is possible to make asser tions about e.g., categories, types, roles, which are typically considered at the meta-level of an ontology. Instances of Concept reify such elements, which are therefore put in the ordinary domain of an ontology. It is not possible to parametrize the classiﬁcation over different dimensions e.g., time, space, etc. </cpannotationschema:hasConsequences>
string"">Mac OSX 10.5 is classiﬁed as an an operating system in the Fujitsu-Siemens product catalog.</cpannotationschema:scenarios>

PlainLiteral"">The classification content ontology design pattern. This CP represents the realtions between concepts e.g., roles, task, and entities to which concepts are assigned to e.g., person, activities. The CP is extracted form DOLCE Ultra Lite ontology.</rdfs:comment>

string"">To represent the relations between concepts (roles, task, parameters) and entities (person, events, values), which concepts can be assigned to. To formalize the application (e.g. tagging) of informal knowledge

column1: organization systems such as lexica, thesauri, subject directories, folksonomies, etc., where concepts are ﬁrst-order elements.</cpannotationschema:hasIntent>

column2: string"">Typically combined with descriptionandsituation. It is specialized by cat:objectrole. The n-ary classiﬁcation CP provides an alternative to this if classiﬁcation has to be qualiﬁed over different dimensions.</cpannotationschema:relatedCPs>
string"">What concept is assigned to this entity? Which category does this entity belong to?</cpannotationschema:coversRequirements>
string"">A relation between a Concept and an Entity, e.g. the Role &#39

column1: <rdfs:comment>A relation between a Concept and an Entity, e.g. &#39
column2: John is considered a typical rude man&#39
column4: your last concert constitutes the achievement of a lifetime

column2: string"">A concept is a Social Object.

column1: The classifies relation relates concepts to entities at some time, but time can only be expressed in the alternative pattern: timeindexedclassification.</rdfs:comment>

column2: string"">1.1 added rdfs:isDefinedBy for all named entities</owl:versionInfo>
PlainLiteral"">Collections and their members can be associated. Time-indexed membership cannot be represented though (you need a situation-based pattern).</cpannotationschema:hasConsequences>
string"">Created by Aldo Gangemi and Valentina Presutti</owl:versionInfo>
PlainLiteral"">My saxophone collection includes a Mark VI tenor, a Balanced Action alto, and a Conn Transitional bari.</cpannotationschema:scenarios>

column1: It is extracted from DOLCE-UltraLite by partial clone of elements.</rdfs:comment>

column2: PlainLiteral"">What things are contained in this collection (community, collective)? What collections this thing is member of?</cpannotationschema:coversRequirements>

column1: <rdfs:comment>A relation between collections and entities, e.g. &#39
column2: my collection of saxophones includes an old Adolphe Sax original alto&#39
column3: (i.e. my collection has member an Adolphe Sax alto).</rdfs:comment>

column1: <rdfs:comment>Any container for entities that share one or more common properties. E.g. &quot
column7: . A collection is not a logical class: a collection is a first-order entity, while a class is a second-order one.</rdfs:comment>

column2: string"">1.1 added rdfs:isDefinedBy for all named entities</owl:versionInfo>
string"">Brain and heart are parts of the human body, substantia nigra is part of brain.</cpannotationschema:scenarios>

string"">The time indexed part of is used as alternative when the temporal indexing has to be represented. Part of CP is specialized by componency. Sometimes this CP is wrongly used in order to model constituency and membership. These two modeling problems are addressed by constituency, and collection entity CPs, respectively.</cpannotationschema:relatedCPs>
string"">This CP allows designers to represent entities and their parts i.e., part-whole relations, with transitivity. The temporal aspect of this relation cannot be expressed
column3: in order to solve this issue the time indexed part of CP can be used.</cpannotationschema:hasConsequences>

column2: string"">To represents entities and their parts.</cpannotationschema:hasIntent>
string"">What is this entity part of? What are the parts of this entity?</cpannotationschema:coversRequirements>

column1: <rdfs:comment>A transitive relation expressing parthood between any entities, e.g. &#39
column2: the human body has a brain as part&#39
column3: . When specializing this pattern, take care of restricting the domain and range appropriately, since it could be counterintuitive to use this relation arbitrarily, e.g. between animals and planets. For an intransitive partof pattern, see &#39

column1: <rdfs:comment>A transitive relation expressing parthood between any entities, e.g. &#39
column2: brain is a part of the human body&#39
column3: . When specializing this pattern, take care of restricting the domain and range appropriately, since it could be counterintuitive to use this relation arbitrarily, e.g. between animals and planets. For an intransitive partof pattern, see &#39
